natural solution: Setting $x = 3,$ we get $f(3) = -1.$ Since $-1 < 2,$ $f(-1) = -a + b.$ Hence, $f(f(3)) = f(-1) = -a + b.$ But $f(f(x)) = x$ for all $x,$ so $-a + b = 3.$ Setting $x = 4,$ we get $f(4) = -4.$ Since $-4 < 2,$ $f(-4) = -4a + b.$ Hence, $f(f(4)) = f(-4) = -4a + b.$ But $f(f(x)) = x$ for all $x,$ so $-4a + b = 4.$
Subtracting the equations $-a + b = 3$ and $-4a + b = 4,$ we get $3a = -1,$ so $a = -1/3.$ From $-a + b = 3,$ we get $b = a + 3 = 8/3.$ Hence, $$a + b = (-1/3) + 8/3 = \boxed{\frac{7}{3}}.$$

(* ### Problem

\begin{array}{cl}

8 - 3x & \text{if } x \ge 2.
\end{array}
\right.\]The function $f$ has the property that $f(f(x)) = x$ for all $x.$ What is $a + b?$ The final Answer is \frac{7}{3}
 ### Proof
 Setting $x = 3,$ we get $f(3) = -1.$ Since $-1 < 2,$ $f(-1) = -a + b.$ Hence, $f(f(3)) = f(-1) = -a + b.$ But $f(f(x)) = x$ for all $x,$ so $-a + b = 3.$ Setting $x = 4,$ we get $f(4) = -4.$ Since $-4 < 2,$ $f(-4) = -4a + b.$ Hence, $f(f(4)) = f(-4) = -4a + b.$ But $f(f(x)) = x$ for all $x,$ so $-4a + b = 4.$

fixes a b :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. x < 2 \<longrightarrow> f x = a * x + b"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. x \<ge> 2 \<longrightarrow> f x = 8 - 3 * x"

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b x :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. x < 2 \<longrightarrow> f x = a * x + b"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. x \<ge> 2 \<longrightarrow> f x = 8 - 3 * x"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. f (f x) = x"
shows  "a + b = 7 / 3"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 For some constants $a$ and $b,$ let \[f(x) = \left\{
\begin{array}{cl}
ax + b & \text{if } x < 2, \\
8 - 3x & \text{if } x \ge 2.
\end{array}
\right.\]The function $f$ has the property that $f(f(x)) = x$ for all $x.$ What is $a + b?$ The final Answer is \frac{7}{3}
 ### Proof
 Setting $x = 3,$ we get $f(3) = -1.$ Since $-1 < 2,$ $f(-1) = -a + b.$ Hence, $f(f(3)) = f(-1) = -a + b.$ But $f(f(x)) = x$ for all $x,$ so $-a + b = 3.$ Setting $x = 4,$ we get $f(4) = -4.$ Since $-4 < 2,$ $f(-4) = -4a + b.$ Hence, $f(f(4)) = f(-4) = -4a + b.$ But $f(f(x)) = x$ for all $x,$ so $-4a + b = 4.$
 Subtracting the equations $-a + b = 3$ and $-4a + b = 4,$ we get $3a = -1,$ so $a = -1/3.$ From $-a + b = 3,$ we get $b = a + 3 = 8/3.$ Hence, $$a + b = (-1/3) + 8/3 = \boxed{\frac{7}{3}}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b x :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. x < 2 \<longrightarrow> f x = a * x + b"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. x \<ge> 2 \<longrightarrow> f x = 8 - 3 * x"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. f (f x) = x"
shows  "a + b = 7 / 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: A function $f(x)$ is defined as $f(x) = ax + b$ for all $x < 2$ and $f(x) = 8 - 3x$ for all $x \ge 2$. If $f(f(x)) = x$ for all $x$, find the sum of $a$ and $b$. The final answer is $\frac{7}{3}$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and a b :: real and f g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "f x = (if x < 2 then a * x + b else 8 - 3 * x)"
and h1 : "g x = (if x < (8 - b) / (3 - a) then a * x + b else 8 - 3 * x)"
and h2 : "\<forall>x. f (g x) = x"
shows  "a + b = 7 / 3"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 For some constants $a$ and $b,$ let \[f(x) = \left\{
\begin{array}{cl}
ax + b & \text{if } x < 2, \\
8 - 3x & \text{if } x \ge 2.
\end{array}
\right.\]The function $f$ has the property that $f(f(x)) = x$ for all $x.$ What is $a + b?$ The final Answer is \frac{7}{3}
 ### Proof
 Setting $x = 3,$ we get $f(3) = -1.$ Since $-1 < 2,$ $f(-1) = -a + b.$ Hence, $f(f(3)) = f(-1) = -a + b.$ But $f(f(x)) = x$ for all $x,$ so $-a + b = 3.$ Setting $x = 4,$ we get $f(4) = -4.$ Since $-4 < 2,$ $f(-4) = -4a + b.$ Hence, $f(f(4)) = f(-4) = -4a + b.$ But $f(f(x)) = x$ for all $x,$ so $-4a + b = 4.$
 Subtracting the equations $-a + b = 3$ and $-4a + b = 4,$ we get $3a = -1,$ so $a = -1/3.$ From $-a + b = 3,$ we get $b = a + 3 = 8/3.$ Hence, $$a + b = (-1/3) + 8/3 = \boxed{\frac{7}{3}}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and a b :: real and f g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "f x = (if x < 2 then a * x + b else 8 - 3 * x)"
and h1 : "g x = (if x < (8 - b) / (3 - a) then a * x + b else 8 - 3 * x)"
and h2 : "\<forall>x. f (g x) = x"
shows  "a + b = 7 / 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Let $f(x) = ax + b$ if $x < 2$ and $f(x) = 8 - 3x$ otherwise. Let $g(x) = ax + b$ if $x < \frac{8 - b}{3 - a}$ and $g(x) = 8 - 3x$ otherwise. If $f(g(x)) = x$ for all $x$, find the sum of $a$ and $b$. The final answer is $\frac{7}{3}$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x a b :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "f = (\<lambda>x. if x < 2 then a * x + b else 8 - 3 * x)"
and h1 : "\<forall>x. f (f x) = x"
shows  "a + b = 7 / 3"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 For some constants $a$ and $b,$ let \[f(x) = \left\{
\begin{array}{cl}
ax + b & \text{if } x < 2, \\
8 - 3x & \text{if } x \ge 2.
\end{array}
\right.\]The function $f$ has the property that $f(f(x)) = x$ for all $x.$ What is $a + b?$ The final Answer is \frac{7}{3}
 ### Proof
 Setting $x = 3,$ we get $f(3) = -1.$ Since $-1 < 2,$ $f(-1) = -a + b.$ Hence, $f(f(3)) = f(-1) = -a + b.$ But $f(f(x)) = x$ for all $x,$ so $-a + b = 3.$ Setting $x = 4,$ we get $f(4) = -4.$ Since $-4 < 2,$ $f(-4) = -4a + b.$ Hence, $f(f(4)) = f(-4) = -4a + b.$ But $f(f(x)) = x$ for all $x,$ so $-4a + b = 4.$
 Subtracting the equations $-a + b = 3$ and $-4a + b = 4,$ we get $3a = -1,$ so $a = -1/3.$ From $-a + b = 3,$ we get $b = a + 3 = 8/3.$ Hence, $$a + b = (-1/3) + 8/3 = \boxed{\frac{7}{3}}.$$
 *)

theorem
fixes x a b :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "f = (\<lambda>x. if x < 2 then a * x + b else 8 - 3 * x)"
and h1 : "\<forall>x. f (f x) = x"
shows  "a + b = 7 / 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Consider a function $f(x) = \begin{cases} ax + b, & \text{if } x < 2 \\ 8 - 3x, & \text{if } x \ge 2 \end{cases}$. Find the values of $a$ and $b$ such that $f(f(x)) = x$ for all $x$. The final answer is $a + b = \frac{7}{3}$.
